title: 112_hr4631
content: The Act titled "Government Spending Accountability Act of 2012" or "GSA Act of 2012" imposes limits and transparency on conference and travel spending. The "Government Spending Accountability Act of 2012" imposes limits and transparency on conference and travel spending, including requirements for agencies to post detailed conference materials on their public websites. The "Government Spending Accountability Act of 2012" sets a $500,000 limit on agency expenditures for a single conference, with the option for the agency head to waive the limit for cost-effective purposes, requiring a report to Congress on any waivers granted. The "Government Spending Accountability Act of 2012" allows agencies to receive financial support from private entities for conferences exceeding $500,000. Agencies cannot pay travel expenses for more than 50 employees for international conferences without approval from the Secretary of State. Quarterly reports on conference expenses must be posted on agency websites. The "Government Spending Accountability Act of 2012" requires agencies to disclose itemized expenses, primary sponsor, location, date, employee participation impact, individuals whose expenses were covered, total number of individuals covered, and a statement for conferences sponsored by the agency. The primary sponsor must provide a detailed description of the cost and selection process for the conference venue, including a cost benefit analysis compared to a teleconference. Any financial support from a private entity must be disclosed, along with a certification of no conflict of interest. Each report posted on the public website must be in a searchable electronic format and remain there for at least 5 years. Definitions include 'agency' as defined in section 5701, and 'conference' as a meeting held for consultation, education, discussion, or training, not entirely at a Government facility. The term 'international conference' refers to a conference outside the US attended by US Government representatives and foreign entities. Annual travel expense limits are set for fiscal years 2013 through 2017, restricting agencies from exceeding 70% of travel expenses incurred in fiscal year 2010. Guidelines for identifying travel expenses must be established by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget by December 31, 2012, in consultation with relevant authorities. The guidelines for determining travel expenses exclude military travel expenses such as combat, training, and deployment of military personnel. Military travel expenses are determined by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget in consultation with relevant authorities. The guidelines for determining travel expenses exclude military travel expenses and are determined by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget in consultation with relevant authorities, including the Administrator of General Services and the Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts. The House of Representatives passed the bill on September 11, 2012. Karen L. Haas attested to it as the Clerk.
